Mr* James A* Fellows
National Association of

1346 Connecticut Avenue, N.W.
Washington 36, D.C.
Progress Report: June 1963
Dear Jim;
This letter constitutes the monthly progress report
which is, as I understand it, required under the provi¬
sions of the agreement between the VOA and the NAEB*
1# 39-scrint series. Drafts of the first 13 scripts
have been completed. However, the typist has not finished
typing them, so I am not able to include them with this
report. I expect to be able to mail them to you by Wednes¬
day. These drafts are subject to very extensive revision,
and we do not consider them in their present state to be
suitable for review by consultants. There must be more
provision for regular review in the materials than we have
so far included; all the scripts must be smoothed out, and
some of the less important patterns must be deleted so as
to permit adequate coverage of the more important patterns.
Further, the scripts must be adjusted to the proper length.
A tentative list of the problems currently scheduled for
each lesson is included as an appendix to this report.
2. 65-script series. Because of the earlier deadline
on the 39-script series, relatively little work has been
done on the 65-script series. I have completed a detailed
analysis of the NOTE textbook, English for Today, volume 1,
and I am now working on the analysis of volume 2. I have
received a draft of volume 3, and I expect to complete my
analyses of both volume 2 and volume 3 in July* I will
then prepare a tentative syllabus for the first 65 lessons,
as stipulated in the agreement.
3. Poetry series. We have not yet been provided with
any material for this series, so we have been unable to do
any work on it.
4. Other activities. I have thus far made two trips
to Washington for discussions concerning this project. The
first trip was on May 23, and the second June 11-13. On
the latter trip I was accompanied by Margery Morris. I
have also had several discussions with Dr. Croodell, the
